AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: The Howler Original Release: 2014 Genre Tags: 2D; Simple; Puzzle; Strategy My Overall Grade: B- Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 2 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Aesthetes; Casual gamersREVIEWI love epic AAA titles that take three full work-weeks to complete just as much as the next guy; but sometimes I also enjoy those short and simple games that are easy to digest after a long day. The Howler is a great example of the latter. It has simple, straightforward mechanics with a pleasing, intimate art style. It is short and gratifyingly challenging without being too frustrating. And there is also an optional Voice-Mode which can be used to add a little dash of flavor to the experience. The game is comprised of a small amount of short levels. Most of them won’t take long to beat. The puzzles involve simple two-dimensional movement which requires timing and precision. It is all very simplistic. But if you want to try out something a little different, you can enable Voice-Mode, which will allow you to use your voice (via humming, whistling, or blowing into the microphone) to control the game. It’s kind of fun at first, but some of the harder levels require a lot of precision and it can be real difficult in Voice-Mode.The hand-drawn artwork is also very nice.  It is a pleasing mix of intimate, curious, and casual. It isn’t the most refined or aweing art, but it is unique and full of character, and it fits the game well.The last thing I’ll mention is that it is very short. To me, short games are great because I love variety and hate leaving things unfinished; but I know some people may have a problem with it, so be aware. Also, I generally try to not discuss price in my reviews, because everyone values a dollar differently depending on their lifestyle. But in this case I do want to say that I feel like the developers have priced this game reasonably considering its length. And so, like I suggested earlier: it is a nice, little game for those times you want something lightweight and intuitive. If that sounds like something you would be interested in, I would recommend you give The Howler some consideration.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

												I will admit, I only bothered to look at this game due to its very cool graphical style. Though, on watching the gameplay video and reading the main synopsis present on the store page, I became fearful of a very real possibility. Namely, that hiding behind an excellent artistic direction is a shallow, and probably irritating, gimmick driven “game”. Not unexpectedly, I’m obliged to report that my suspicions proved accurate, but also that my discoveries come with several reservations.First, the gameplay itself (and this should be obvious from the accompanying trailers), is minimal. The goal is to slowly raise and lower your balloon in tune with the weather patterns, which push you left and right, to varying degrees, and land at some designated point. As the game goes on, you’ll have to contend with the added complexity of doing this several times per level, and occasionally even drop things down holes or bombs on unsuspecting flying spiky balls. Playing with a standard mouse, this gets boring, and at times irritating, though mostly due to the slow nature of your balloon and having to wait for your chance to fail again. Chances are, you will have to reset levels several times due to popping or floating too far off-screen. This is where the gimmick comes in, and the developers clearly hope that people haven’t learned from every other throwaway peripheral and gimmick that console makers try to push down our throats. By using your mic, you can control the balloon with your voice. Or any manner of sound, I suppose, so long as you can easily fluctuate it. This is also where my first aforementioned reservation comes in. If you can entertain yourself for hours on end by making stupid noises in the dark, than by all means, play and thoroughly enjoy The Howler. If you’re considering this as a fun diversion for you and your drunk friends, ask yourself this – when was the last time you were able to keep a group of drunks quiet for more than 5 seconds? If you can’t answer that question, than you’re better dusting off the ol’ Kinect for another go around of drunk digital soccer.Now here’s my second reservation: the art design. It is superb, often ranging from the melancholy to the downright foreboding. And of course, the Wolf. It really bothers me that such a fantastic art style is wasted on a game like this. Given that this mediocre excursion could be beaten in little more than hour (provided you’re forced to reset as often as I had to), than I would seriously consider recommending this title given you have a fondness for such things. If you can forgive, or at the very least tolerate the gameplay, than you may have a better time than I did, if only for the joy of viewing the set pieces. Know, though, that for some reason the game is limited to a small window (surrounded by a large black border in fullscreen), and cannot appear to be changed. While this keeps the art crisp and clean, I am disappointed that I couldn’t have a closer look at some of the better murals.The Howler is based off of a book, and you’ll see a direct link to it on Amazon.com in the game’s menu. It’s a shame that there is absolutely no exposition or plot to the game’s events, offering only a quick phrase explaining your mission for whatever group and off you go!. Perhaps it might have alleviated the boredom of the actual gameplay mechanic to have given it all a more defined purpose. In any case, The Howler is something you probably shouldn’t even bother playing in the first place. Unless you really think you’re going to enjoy making stupid noises into your mic for an hour, or absolutely refuse to use google to find the game’s sublime artwork, I’d recommend you at least find a better mobile port to spend your time on.

												I was very surprised by this short but sweet game, particularly considering how cheap it is. The premise of the game, to control a hot air balloon, is very simple, yet made interesting by the challenge of having to navigate often precarious routes. The game's controls are intuitive, as the only control over the balloon the player has is to increase its altitude, and to drop objects. The balloon's direction and speed are left to the whim of the wind, as the wind direction and speed alter according to altitude. By keeping both the premise and mechanics of the game simple and intuitive, yet introducing a new idea or challenge with each of 16 levels, the game kept me both intrigued and somewhat intellectually stimulated. Some aspects of the game I particularly enjoyed are the art style and music, and ability to use audio as a form of input instead of the mouse, which works very well. However, as with almost any game, there are a few aspects I would have liked to see imrpoved. Firstly, the inability to rebind controls, such as using the arrow keys instead of left click, the fact that the game doesn't scale with screen size, meaning there is a lot of unused black space around it, and the inability to move the camera independently from the balloon as I sometimes felt that my field of view was unnecessarily constrained. Yet, despite all of its flaws, I was left thouroughly satisfied by the game, and despite only taking up to an hour to complete, I would not expect any more for its price.

												The Howler is a game of dexterity and timing in which you control a hot air balloon. Clicking the mouse (or making noise if you have a compatible microphone) makes the balloon go up. In each level, you need to manoeuvre the balloon through a parcours by making use of the wind. There are areas in which the wind blows the balloon forward and there are areas in which the wind blows the balloon back.At first, this simple idea looks promising. The first few levels are fun. But soon, the real difficulty pops up: level after level, you need to manoeuvre the balloon through spikey things. And the balloon snaps on the slightest contact with spikey things, so it requires perfect timing. At that point, you realize the game is actually a lot like an unforgiving old-school platformer game. You know, a game that requires you to try and try again until you pretty much know the exact timing to get through each level. I'm sure a lot of people enjoy games like that, and they will enjoy The Howler for what it is, but I think it's only fair to warn other people about the nature of this game because it doesn't show from the description and the screenshots.What you can tell from watching the screenshots, is that the artwork is very nice and pretty unique for an indie game like this. It's also a cheap game, especially when on sale, so if you're not sure whether to try it after reading this and some other reviews, I'd say give it a go. But because the Howler is not the sort of game I expected and because I simply didn't enjoy the game for what it turned out to be, I can't generally recommend this game so I feel obligated to click the 'thumbs down' button.

-Quick Review-The Howler is a short indie hot air balloon simulator developed by Antanas Marcelionis and released in mid 2014.-Detailed breakdown review-Story: There is a progressive story about the “Viceroy of Vilnius, Antanas Sidabras”, that is told through the 15 levels of the game. (not including bonus levels)Aesthetically speaking, the game has some really visually interesting graphics; the art is hand drawn and the “architecture actually exists in Vilnius today”, according to Antanas Marcelionis.


By the way, when I screenshot, I drop whatever I'm carrying, so I dropped a bomb right after taking this... haha 
A Screenshot of The Howler
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: There are two control choices: the volume of your voice (obviously requiring a functional microphone on your computer), when the microphone picks up your voice being loud enough, your hot air balloon goes up.Alternatively, simply use a keyboard, pressing space to go up, and then any other key drops your cargo (including your Steam screenshot button, so beware the screenshot!)You need to dodge objects that may pop your balloon, and move into air currents that will push you to the right or left. While the game is very straightforward and controls very easily, it's definitely not an “easy” game.


This level.... *heavy breathing* 
A Screenshot of The Howler
By: Atratzu




Achievements: There are no steam achievements for The Howler, quite frankly there isn't enough game to give very many achievements. If achievements were added at some point, it would be along the lines of “beat the game”, “find the hidden level codes”, and anything else would be along the lines of "high score".Price: The Howler is priced at $4.99, I spent only 1.5 hours to beat the game. By my value system (1 dollars for every hour played), this game is a bit too high priced. However, when on sale it's a fair price.In the end, the developers are indie so the prices tend to be lower and go on sale often, you could argue for buying the game just to support the developers.Conclusion: The game was short and sweet. The only problem is that I don't really feel like this game was designed for a computer. It felt like something you'd play on an iPad, or mobile device.I enjoyed playing it. I recommend this game to anyone who wants to play a neat unique game for a couple of hours. I suggest getting it on sale, or purchasing for a mobile device.

												The Howler Review - Raymond KTFollowing the general outline of the Lithuanian novel The Hour of the Wolf by Andrius Tapinas, the game is set in an alternate steampunk version of Vilnius, Lithuania. In order to observe the goings on around the city, Antanas Sadabras, the legate of Vilnius, takes to his hot air balloon. During his observations, Antanas discovers that rioters are planning an attack on the city and that they have released automatons throughout the airspace as part of their scheme. With his precious city in peril, it is up to Antanas to stop the rioters and return Vilnius to normalcy. The story is simple, straightforward, and is presented to players through minimalist snippets of text just before you begin a mission. It's not extensive and it's not complex, but it gets the job done. That being said, I'm a sucker for a good story, and I would have loved a bit more insight into what exactly provoked these riots. In all honesty, though, this games isn't really about the story...I thought the concept of the game was fun, simple. Get to one destination from another. All of the artwork was done the tried and true way: drawn by hand on paper. HAND DRAWN!!! Overall, if you like platformers with highly sensitive controls, you will love The Howler. On the other hand, if you’re easily frustrated with games in this genre, you may want to spend the money on something less confounding…like a nice book about political intrigue!

All you can do is increase the heat to ascend or subsequently release the hot air to descend.  By controlling the elevation you will pass through different zones of air blowing the wind this way and that way.  Certain currents will be stronger than other and you must be careful of the potential momentum of the stronger winds.  By straddling these currents you can proceed to your destination or pick up goods required for the different objectives.Many levels will simply have to going for one spot to another.  Other levels may have you pick up and deliver a package.  Later in the game you'll be given bombs you can drop.  Use these to destroy obstacles in your path or take out the enemy's bridge.  Just be careful not to be too close to your bombs as you can easily be sent floating off screen and into the abyss.One of the coolest parts of the game is the hand drawn art.  The backgrounds are gorgeous and rich with detail.  They distinguish themselves nicely from the sharp,clean, lines of the objects in the foreground.  There isn't much to the sound design.  There isn't any music while playing which could be justified to help you concentrate.  Usually all you hear is balloon's propane kicking in as you turn on the heat to ascend.  That being said the automatons and cars really stick out in the levels they're present.There really isn't much else to say.  This is a really simple game, one that doesn't take long to finish.  That isn't necessary a bad thing considering the low price point.  Not to mention there really isn't many other games like it.  The unique art style might make it worth considering if you're on edge.  As long as you're not expecting anything too fancy there is fun to be had playing The Howler.

												(This copy of the game was provided freely by EpicQuest Games)I don't particularly like to ragequit a game, but this is the first one that's driven me to do so in a while.The Howler has a lot of things a good game should have. There's the unique concept of using your voice (or noise in general) to move your hot air balloon around the map. The artwork is beautiful and really worth taking a good time to enjoy. That's where it stops. Right there is where The Howler ceases and I find myself completely irritated with the game.There is simplicity in the game. You are delivering parcels and you don't want your balloon oblierated on the ornate and breath-taking buildings. That's great and that would appeal to a wide audience there. That's perfect. Yet here's what flubs it up. The wind and weather direction should be something that gives you a slight challenge, not forces you to constantly restart the level because the angle wasn't just perfect so your balloon didn't pop or you didn't fly too high into the heavens. I've played similar games to this before and especially when you're starting out, they're a lot more forgiving with their wind merchanics. The Howler punishes you mercilessly on level 3 and continues to kick you in the stomach with that mechanic until you've had enough and switch the game off.There's also the fact that the voice control, even when your microphone is on the most sensitivity possible, will not be enough to keep your balloon afloat. Now I'm aware that the game suggested I scream, but not everyone using Steam is living in a house where we have enough privacy to scream. If I have to make my voice raw to get that thing off the ground, why am I playing the game at all? That's entirely too much work and I'm not getting a sore throat just to play it.The screens betwen levels are charming and give me the option to turn off the microphone (your mouse will be easier to play with at this rate, I suppose!) but little exposition except a bit of real life history of the city. There's no actual substansial story here and I was expecting a tiny bit more, given I felt teased with the artwork and fairly let down by game play.It's like a really pretty flappy bird with a harder obstacle course you're supposed to scream at. I just didn't feel the need to open my big trap since it doesn't actually help!Accessibility warnings? Transition screens are bright and have a white light. May cause migraines or seizures if you're sensitive. It certainly brought me a migraine. The repetitive motion of clicking upward gets sore (and pretty old!) fast as well.

Posted: April 9
												This game features an interesting and unique art style that gives a warm, yet delightfully bleak impression due to its limited color palette of autumn colors. This wonderfully rich world is painted with a variety of shades, including earthly reds, moody oranges and warm bronze. In my opinion, the interesting choice of colour represents a particular time of day when winds are most calm to traverse along with a traditional autumn season. The culture of the narrative is represented mainly in it's architecture, which are presented as obstacles throughout the game. These buildings are very detailed and is clearly the work of a talented artist. Unfortunately, apart from on-screen text that shows the player's objective and motivations, the building's style is the only visual means of connecting the player to the game world. This isn't necessarily a bad thing for such a short, independent title, but it leaves a strong desire to dive deeper into it's limited narrative once all levels are completed. The game is almost entirely played with a single tap of a mouse or screen, with the exception of the spacebar. Despite it's simple mechanics, the gameplay can be very challenging at certain levels. Espically at the beginning of the game, where the pilot is tasked to fly beyond a collosal monstrosity of a howling wolf to retrieve a set of packages before returning to the glorious canine to descend into it's steel belly. The hour that you will typlically spend playing 'The Howler' will be an artisticaly inspirational and rewarding hour. I would gladly reccommend the game for anyone who appreciates art or has a simple hour to spend.

												The game has a wonderful art style which is a combination of hand sketching and watercolor wash. The setting is steampunk and you play as a hotair balloon pilot. You have some control over the upward and downward motion of the balloon but you are at the mercy of the wind currents to move left and right. You will need to use momentum to navigate around obstacles, using the wind to your advantage and quickly changing elevation. The difficulty of the game ramps up quite quickly. On most levels (missions) you will be picking up and/or dropping parcels. There is a great deal of verticality in the game and often your destinations will be outside of your view. Each mission starts with a quick scan over the scene, but it will be up to you to remember where you need to go. You can control the game with your mouse and keyboard, but you can also control it with your voice. I tried this feature but found it less appealing than traditional controls. The game has a 4x3 aspect ratio and is locked at 30 FPS. I suspect this is due to it being available on iOS as well. Given how the level design works they would not have been able to simply expand the aspect ratio. This may be off-putting to some but the game can run in windowed mode so you won't notice any wasted space. In full screen you will have black bars on the sides. You cannot control the volume in the game, you'll have to rely on the system sound controls. This is probably another aspect of its iOS support.Overall I enjoyed my time with the game so far and I will play more of it. If you like to be in complete control of your "character" you may not enjoy this title since a lot of the time the control is out of your hands.If you'd like to see 20 minutes of my experience with the game check out my Twenty Minute Tryout video on YouTube...

												Summary: I can't swallow the broken physics and without it there is no game.Right:Hot Air balloons can be controlled with a single "burn" input (one button), sending the hot-air balloon upwards. Think "Flappy Bird", not "Kerbal SPace Program".Wrong:The only thing that makes this a "game" (instead of a "follow the arrows" exercise) is that physics is twisted so that the balloon can gain momentum in one windstream, and when the balloon enters a different windstream, the balloon will briefly continue moving as though it were still in the first windstream. Neither Boyle, Bernoulli nor Newton would have approved this game-design decision. It's not how balloons work in air. And without this twist there is no game.Wrong:The player can hear the burn when the balloon is ordered to move upwards, suggesting a warm balloon filled with mostly Nitrogen and Carbon Dioxide. Yet the balloon detonates when it strikes an object, as thought the balloon were constructed of strike-anywhere matches and filled with hydrogen.Wrong:The balloon can go seemingly infinitely far off the map to the left, right, or bottom. But if it goes off the top of the map, it is "lost" and forces a restart. What, did it go into orbit? Doesn't the air on this planet get thinner with altitude?Wrong:No fuel meter, infinite burns are allowed. Fuel should have been the "game", and physics should have been real.

YouTube™ Video: The Howler - let's play & first impressions

			This is my first impressions of The Howler by Antanas Macelionis & Rene Petruliene. Enjoy. I also posted my review on steam.		

The game looks great. It's very peaceful, there not a lot of sound or music aside from your own voice. Only problem I had was that I coudln't put the game into fullscreen. So the footage I made of the game is essentially in letterbox format (I should have lowered the desktop resolution).You control the altitude of a hot air baloon with a the mouse or by the making sound into a microphone. Lateral movement depends on the strength and direction of the air current you are in. So you have to navigate the air currents. Each level has a different objective e.g. to start you just have to fly to the landing pad and later you need to pick up and deliver parcels.It's a lot of fun to use voice to control the hot air Baloon. I lost control several times when I spoke or burst into laughter which would seen the baloon rising out of the boundaries of the level. So I had to make myself shut sometimes lol. The game gets pretty tricky fast. It will make you navigate through currents pushing against you. The only way to do so is by gaining momentum in a current moving in the correct direction. I had back track a lot and it can be pretty slow using the air currents. But you need to concentrate to create just the right amount of sound. You are supposed to be able to drop objects by using your voice. But I couldn't get this to work so I used the space bar.So it is a really cool game and $2.99 is an awesome price.Click here for more let’s play videos =)

												The Howler is a beautiful but whisper-thin sort of puzzle game that'll provide you with about an hour of entertainment. You pilot a balloon through a very nicely handpainted 2D representation of Vilnius, Lithuania, done up all steampunk-like. You press the mouse button to provide thrust which carries the balloon higher—steering is left up to the winds which're denoted on the side of the screen. Using those winds you steer around, over, and under obstacles and enemies to reach your goal, which always consists of picking up and/or dropping off items before plopping down on a landing pad elsewhere in the level.That's really it. Lunar Lander with some extra physics. There's a story attached involving impending riots and your efforts to stave them off supposedly taken from or relating in some way to the Lithuanian novel Hour of the Wolf, but like the rest of the game it's pretty insubstantial.There's also an option to use your PC's microphone to control the balloon with your voice, which I didn't use at all. One, it feels like a bit of a gimmick which I don't consider to be either innovative or even essential to gameplay. If the voice commands were integrated into the experience in some way that made them inseperable—or even more effective than just clicking the mouse—I might take the concept seriously, but it seems more like the developer asking you to handicap yourself to make its game seem deeper than it really is. You can play Snake with a Dance Dance Revolution pad, but that doesn't make it innovative, it's still just Snake. Two, I have roommates.All that said the levels are well designed—occasionally cunningly so—and it is very well presented with lovely artwork and music, giving the game a cohesive style that kept me relatively engrossed for the 58 minutes it lasted.I picked this up for $0.49 during the Autumn Sale. The HowlerThis review was last edited after I had completed the first 15 levelsShort ReviewA delightful game with beautiful, hand drawn graphics & simple game play that whilst only mildly challenging is fun to play none the less.Long ReviewThere is no tutorial but adequate hints are provided in the first few levels and the game play is so simple the lack of a tutorial is not an issue.The game is set in 2D with beautiful, hand drawn graphics. The game play is simple. You control a got air balloon that you must direct from one point to another, performing simple tasks like dropping off parcels along the way. The audio is restricted to sound effects which are fairly limited but effective.The controls are simple, for vertical control you press the left mouse button to ignite the hot air and raise and stop pressing it to allow gravity to take over. For left and right control you must rely on the wind direction and speed which varies at different altitudes and is indicated by an arrow on the left hand side; the number of feathers in the quill indicating the strength. Thus you need to be at the correct altitude to move in the correct direction. The SPACE BAR is used to drop objects you are carrying and there is a pause button click able by the mouse.You cannot pan around so you only see a screens worth of the level around the current location of the balloon. If you go too high, low, left or right and disappear off the edge of the level you die. Similarly if the balloon hits other objects you will usually die.As you progress through levels additional obstacles like floating bombs are introduced. Fortunately these move in a predictable manner.The only way to play is via a campaign of different screen levels you play in order (although once you have completed a level you can replay it at any time). The levels are pretty small (maybe twice the width of the monitor). When you start a new level you are quickly shown what needs to be done by the camera panning about and short text messages appearing. You have a set time limit to complete the tasks.This game play is short and the game can be easily be completed in 2-3 hours. Ignore my 17 hours game play - I left the game running in the start menu overnight by mistake.ProsBeautiful, hand drawn graphicsSimple game playConsThe sequence at the start of a level to show you what to do moves along a little fast for me to read all of the textMarks Out Of 55) Must have - stop whatever you're playing now and play this4) Worth the asking price and considering as your next purchase3) Maybe purchase if you're stuck for choosing your next game or mildly discounted2) Only purchase if it is heavily discounted1) Not worth getting even if given away freeWhere I got the game fromI have no idea how this game got into my Steam library but boy am I glad it did!Platform Played OnIntel Pentium G3258 Anniversary Edition, 8Gb RAM, Palit GTX 750, Windows 10, EasyAcc Mouse and Steelseries Merc keyboardMy best guess for a  PEGI Rating 3: I can't see any reason to raise it above this. 												In this air current and physics based game you will have to navigate safely through level upon level completing tasks while on the clock. In this 2D game you will spend most of your time in a hot air balloon where you will have to master the different speeds of the air currents while taking into consideration that air can blow in both directions.Graphically The Howler definitely has that aged look to it. I don't mean that it looks dated it just looks more like a steam-punk Victorian age type of feel. One of the things I like about the art style in this game is that it gives you the look of a city or area of the city while not overly cluttering up the screen. This game is basically played with just a couple of buttons and/or your voice. I know that sounds a bit crazy, but if you have a good enough mic you can issues increases and decreases in altitude by the level of your voice. Do you want to go higher, get louder, you want to descend, well just get quieter. I wouldn't recommend being silent that might cause a not so fun crash, but hey you never know until you try it.One of the things that really impressed me with The Howler was the fact that if you had the tutorial text on you could easily pick up this game and be able to play it. Now I know that there are games that put you through the tutorial once and then disable, but in this game it doesn't and that's not a problem. Instead of constantly taking the player out of the game by throwing up dialogue boxes that you have to click ok or next on they put the text into the background of the game and once you start moving around it just vanishes.Now there is a slight downside to this game and that is it DEFINITELY feels like a port of a tablet or phone game. The resolution for the game can't be changed so you'll be faced with playing in a small box on your screen. The other thing is that as easy as the controls are for some reason the mouse button just doesn't seem to translate as well as say a tap and hold on a touchscreen, maybe that's just me, but I think it makes a difference.So if you are looking for a challenging puzzle game to play with some interesting yet simple controls you are going to want to pick up this game. I'm not going to lie there are definitely some of the levels where it took me more tries than it should have, but that sense of accomplishment when you do gain enough speed to negate the wind going the opposite direction, or the precision flying/floating required to navigate treacherous locations is pretty astounding. So with that I'm giving this game a 7.5 out of 10.
